characters: THE TOP OF THE COAST, THE END OF THE WORLD, EXACTLY LIKE
RAPID FIRE IMAGES UNDERSCORE THE ERA

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: Seen abstractly: manicured green lawn lined with row upon of folding chairs occupied by capped and gowned graduates various viewpoints and perspectives, fresh faces, bright eyes, smiles. Hope and expectation in bright June sunlight. A PA SYSTEM issues final echoing words of an impassioned commencement speech.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: ..-and every person’s fight with death is over before it begins. What makes the struggle worthwhile, therefore, cannot lie in the outcome, but in the dignity in which the fight is waged. Voice swallowed by a vortex of thundering applause. Hover dreamlike images flicker - proud parents, caps launched skyward, bodies scattering, clustered groups, a collage o camera flash. FOUR MALE GRADUATES- bodies edge into semi-focus: One taller, one wider, one darker, one narrower. They amble, shuffle and preen. We don’t engage them as they come to a top step, arms ove shoulders and around waists, until they become one unit, shape. Comrades, chums, buds, mates. Best Friends Forever. Pointed in various freezes and poses by unseen photograph they shift and reassemble and blow out in the camera flas With the final flash of white we see PURE WHITE, forming a A HUGE MOUND OF WHITE POWDER...

dialogues.speaker: RAPID FIRE IMAGES UNDERSCORE THE ERA
dialogues.text: Needle drops on vinyl, music blares, Walkman, Ray-Bans, r blades, lines high speed, mouths suck alcohol, albums of bands we love - Undertones, X, Buzzcocks, Ramones, Englis Beat

dialogues.speaker: FROM ABOVE
dialogues.text: Four male shapes huddle around a glass table, A LARGE SHE OF PAPER in the center. CUT FROM ONE HAND TO ANOTHER HAND WRITING WORDS: promise ...never forget what this feels like...to forget is to FA

dialogues.speaker: FROM BELOW
dialogues.text: Faces as shapes, bend to the glass, toward us, rolled bil nostrils, gleams in eye, fast-slow-fast, focus of vision, intention, desire, animated. We feel all this in our gut. From four corners of the screen, hands reach out to each other, stacking on each other in some communal mask or te agreement, descending and blocking our view until the screen goes BLACK TITLE: JONATHAN, 44.

dialogues.speaker: EST. LOS ANGELES- DAY 2
dialogues.text: An generic office building in Santa Monica

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DOCTOR, handsome, drawn, clean shaven, crisp white doct jacket. Goes through the motions as he treats a wealthy WOMAN (late 40's). She sits on the examination table, texting on her Blackbe as she answers Jonathan without looking up. He’s bored an so is she - this is simply a formality.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: So it’s your hands, nonspecific, but uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: PATIENT
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: You need something for the pain.

dialogues.speaker: PATIENT
dialogues.text: I need something for the pain.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Jonathan nods, writes out a prescription: Oxycontin. She stops texting, takes cash out of her bag, lays it bare on examination table. She takes the prescription, leaves without saying goodby Jonathan removes a pill bottle from his jacket, takes a p from it, dry swallows it. His eye looks at the money, and then is caught by his med degree on the wall. It seems to mock him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing. End of the ride. Jonathan’s six-year-old so MILES rides a carousel horse while Jonathan waits and watches. The Jonathan we met in the office is manifestly different than here. He is buoyant, illuminated from within by the life-force of his Son. Miles climbs off the horse, bolts to Jonathan, smiles as runs. Jonathan bends to greet Miles, lifts him, carries h

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: First time by yourself! Daddy’s so proud of you. Jonathan turns to leave the carousel area. Miles looks at his father’s face, touches it as they walk.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I wasn’t scared.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: I know, I could see that. I was so proud of you-- They walk a few steps until the hear a WOMAN’S VOICE call

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Miles? They look up, see JANE, Jonathan’s ex-wife, Miles’ mother She’s with her husband DANIEL (40's). Jonathan’s face fal he glances at his watch, sadly realizing visiting time is over. As Miles squirms free of Jonathan, Jonathan rushes this out...

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Daddy will see you in two weeks... .--but Miles is already out of his grasp, bolting toward mom. JONATHAN (CONT’D) (under his breath) Bye Miles... When Miles is directly between Jane and Jonathan, he stop looks back, waves at Jonathan, hurries to his mother. Jonathan and Jane make eye contact. Ten years of marriage a few seconds of silence. Miles, his Mother and Daniel turn and walk away, Miles between them holding their hands. Jonathan’s eyes go dead as he watches them leaving...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large house in a decidedly upscale neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bathroom is LARGE. Modern. A TV in the connecting bedroom BLARES BUSINESS news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN leans against the marbled wall, listening, stressed He swears under his breath on certain bits of arcane stock/bond/index information.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: Ron’s wife AMANDA calls out from the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ron? His transformation from stressed to cheery is uncanny.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Hi babe! She turns the business news down.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: You okay in there, hon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always. Yes my dear, why?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Don’t want you to miss your flight.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Gettin’ out now. Amanda turns the business news back up and the distress returns to Ron’s face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron walks in, overnight bag in hand, sees his daughters, CARRIE (16) and JODY (10) and CARLY (8).

dialogues.speaker: JODY /CARLY/CARRIE
dialogues.text: Hi Daddy. Carly draws, and Jody looks up from her laptop screen, smiles, goes back to it.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: My princesses. Carrie moves to him, hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: CARRIE
dialogues.text: Promise me we'll talk about the new car when you get back?

dialogues.speaker: JODY
dialogues.text: If Carrie gets a car then what do I get?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Carrie--

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: A poke in the eye with a sharp stick.

dialogues.speaker: JODY
dialogues.text: (eye roll) That’s so dumb.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I like your Father’s little sayings. Amanda and Ron smile at each other. Kiss.  10

dialogues.speaker: CARRIE
dialogues.text: I need some money for the weekend. Ron reaches in his wallet, takes out twenties, peels off for her. Wait. She looks at him with puppy-dog eyes. He gives her more. 100. 200. 300. Now she hugs him. He kisses the children he loves. Amanda and Ron walk to t front door. Amanda dusts something off his shoulder, straightens his lapel.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: You take care of us, now you deserve to take care of you. Have fun with your friends, Ron. They embrace and kiss again in a heartfelt way.

dialogues.speaker: EST. BOSTON
dialogues.text: Cloudy skies. Bean Town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Class is over. A PUBLIC SCHOOL MIX of TEENS (approx 13 ye old) file out. The TEACHER erases the chalkboard.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: Richard turns toward exiting Students, yells over the din

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Enjoy your week of freedom, and you will be reminded each time you crack open A Farewell To Arms, I have infringed upon your week of freedom. (then) And I am resolutely not sorry. A couple of amused looks from the students tells us they Richard. One kid, JAVIER sits at the back of the class, waits for others to leave. Richard makes eye contact with him. RICHARD (CONT’D) Dr. J, step into my office. Javier stands, walks to the front of the class holding so papers.  11 12 13

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT
dialogues.text: Richard sits on the edge of his desk, Javier sits in the front row. Richard holds Javier's paper.

dialogues.speaker: JAVIER
dialogues.text: But teach, I worked my ass off on this. Richard reads some of Javier's text, then looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: The problem is, you are not here. I don’t see you. You're writing but you're... (searches for the word) You're hiding. Richard hands it back to him. Javier looks in Richard's eyes, tries to absorb the words.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you want people to feel anything, you have to be willing to expose yourself. Javier is not sure what he means. RICHARD (CONT’D) Confess, explore, say things people are afraid of saying. Unleash your shit, Javier, make the words your weapons. Javier stands, Richard slaps him five and Javier turns to leave. Richard watches him go for a beat. He reaches into his pocket, pulls out cell phone, dials. And as it rings...

dialogues.speaker: EST. PORTLAND
dialogues.text: A loft building downtown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Large loft apartment. The person who lives here has good taste and money. A MAN walks into the shot.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: We hear his house phone RING and then:  RICHARD’S VOICE (ON MACHINE) Timothy? This, my friend, is your friend, Richard. We will be celebrating your birthday on this little holiday, yes? See? I did not forget you. I will never forget you. Big Sur, sir. You have all the info, just look for the balloons on the gate. Tim smiles, but there’s subtle melancholy in it. His doorbell rings, he moves to answer it, brightens as he op the door and sees LISA (30's).

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Hello, Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Hello, Tim They smile at each other. And as Tim closes the door...

dialogues.speaker: LISA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There he is! She indicates a CAT lounging on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Doing what he does best.

dialogues.speaker: A MINUTE LATER
dialogues.text: Tim stands in the open kitchen area with Lisa. There is a note with instructions and money on the table. There’s also a sealed envelope on the table marked “Lisa

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here’s the money for this week. (re the sealed envelope) If I’m not back by Sunday, this has more money for you.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Sure you don’t mind staying here?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: This is a palace compared to my hovel.  14 15

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Okay then. I’m gonna finish getting ready. They say goodbye with a cheek kiss, Lisa heads for the do

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Leese? She stops, turns, looks at Tim. He indicates the cat.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take good care of my guy.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: As always. Lisa leaves. Tim moves across the large open space of his loft to his picks up an old wrinkled note, an aged sheet of paper cov in writing. He studies it. We see fragments of writing in different hands, four different signatures. We recognize it from th opening. Tim carefully rolls up the sheet of paper, and walks out the shot.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFFS OF BIG SUR
dialogues.text: We glide over the sea toward the coast, to a house sittin the precipice. A song begins, faintly at first, growing louder as we move in. A lone figure stands on the edge of the back deck of the house looking out to sea. When we are close enough we see it’s Richard, drink in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His POV. Slowing on HIGHWAY ONE as we see four different colored balloons tied to an electronic gate. Tim smiles a he pulls onto the driveway.  16 17 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His rental pulls up next to a classic 80’s Porsche Targa, gets out of the car, stares at the house. He hears music blasting inside. He grabs his bag, walks to the front doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim steps in. The house is huge, modern, flooded with lig Windows everywhere and they’re all open. He walks down the hallway to an enormous living room--- W billows the curtains. We can almost feel the ocean in her Tim moves to the stereo, music deafening, turns it down.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Hello? Richard appears. He and Tim stare at each other a moment. Old friends. Big smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: First thing he does is turn my fucking music down. A familiarity. Richard moves to him, they embrace, happy see each other. Comfort in the years. Richard releases, l at Tim’s face and body. RICHARD (CONT’D) You don’t age. What’s the secret? Let’s sell it and get rich. Tim smiles. Richard gestures to lines of coke on the coff table. RICHARD (CONT’D) Yes? For old times? It’s cold and forsaken here.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Maybe a drink. To start anyway. (beat) Love the car by the way. Very you.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I bought it from some guy on the way from the airport. Saw the for sale sign and boom, impulse buy. Richard moves to the coffee table, bends toward the mirro  11.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I intend to destroy it within the next five days. -..and sniffs a line of coke as Tim watches.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Some things never change Richard. Richard flashes a million dollar smile. For all his brava charm is his currency. Richard sees something in Tim, som change, a dimming of the lights in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What is it? The big four five? You don’t have to worry. They are all the same. The gentle joshing bounces off the pain. Richard's eye is caught by a necklace on Tim’s neck - simple but tasteful pendant with initials. Tim holds it out.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Jill's. I've been wearing it again. Five years ago this month. Richard doesn’t flinch, looks right at his friend.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Jesus. I Can’t believe it’s been that long. Unfucking real. I’m so sorry. Tim nods.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Every time I see you, without fail, you say those words, and I always believe you. And you never try to tell me to forget. Richard gives Tim a deep hug. He comes out of it, relieve at the respite of smiling.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: But per usual, I will be the reminder that this week is about forgetting about all that, just for a moment. Like a magician pulling a rabbit from a hat, he shoves th mirror under Tim’s nose, raises his eyebrows ala Belushi Animal House. Tim can’t help but laugh.  18 19 20 21 22 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim and Richard sit on the deck. Richard's iPhone beeps. looks at it. A text message: when love, love will tear us apart, again. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Ronaldo’s here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TAXI slows near the entrance of the gated driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As it rolls to a stop. A LOCAL drives. Ron in back, stari out the taxi window.

dialogues.speaker: TAXI DRIVER
dialogues.text: (in rear view to Ron) Here? He sees the four colored balloons hovering from the electronic gate. Laughs.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yessir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music plays. Ron opens the refrigerator. It is stocked with wine, vodka, beer. And nothing else. He nods with co approval, turns to the counter, sees bottles of scotch, tequila, rum, Jagermeister. He grabs his laptop - we see an image of his older daught Carrie on the screen - off the kitchen counter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron looks at Richard and Tim.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: My liver just had a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You need anything else, I’1l get it tomorrow. He hands his laptop to Tim.  13.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: This is her.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: So pretty. She’s all grown up, Ron.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Crazy, right? Tim passes the laptop to Richard. He studies her image.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: She getting cock yet? Tim looks at Richard, closes his eyes in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I pray for your soul, Richard.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You can’t pray for a soulless man. Richard looks at Ron, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Let me ask you this Ronaldo: when your daughter’s hot 16 year-old friends come over, do you sometimes wonder what it would be like to fuck them in the ass until they’re cross-eyed? Ron’s reluctance to answer instantly gives Richard his opening... RICHARD (CONT’D) See? See? I told you! Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up and pass me the blow.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I merely say what others think but fear saying. Tim passes Ron a CD cover with a mound of cocaine on it a Ron does a line. Beat. He looks at Richard. Then Tim. He grabs them and they embrace. They release each other and Ron looks aroun  23 24 14.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: For the first time in the fucking history of internet real estate photography the place looks as big in real life as it did online.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: It’s beautiful Ron, perfect. (then) Let’s settle up when you feel like.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: It’s already settled. Richard and Tim’s eyes meet.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: The rich are different from you and me, Timothy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fingers punch a code on the gate keypad, it hums to life slowly swings open. A MAN walks down the driveway in the darkness carrying a suitcase and a satchel bag toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the man emerge from the shadows and into the light It’s Jonathan. He watches his friends inside the house a beat. He moves to the sliding glass window. All they have to do look up. They don’t. He slides open the door and his face brightens.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Jonathan! Jonathan smiles, moves inside. The guys greet him.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: The doctor is in! Jonathan shakes his briefcase, we hear the rattling of prescription bottles.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: He most certainly is.  25 26 27 15.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What and how much?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Enough to treat the illnesses at hand. Now make me a drink while I urinate and get settled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonathan places prescription bottles on a dresser - Dilau Oxycontin, Adderall, Fentanyl, Librium, Ketamine. He spea a fragment from the Hippocratic oath to himself as he doe

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Whatever houses I may visit, I will come for the benefit of the sick, remaining free of injustice and all mischief...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moon and stars in the sky. Silence surrounds this remote house. We hear laughter and music inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC LOUD. Ron, Richard, Jonathan and Tim sit around the large coffee table, talking over the music. A solid blissed-out buzz, perfect mix of alcohol, coke, trust, time and freedom. Enough drugs to last, no responsibilities. Chatter is fast, they know each other’s rhythm like a band that’s played together many times.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: .--no no no, it’s a food aversion.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Women get it during pregnancy. Certain foods make them sick, even the smell. Richard snorts a line off a CD cover, passes it to Jonath

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Are there any particular foods that-

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (interrupts) You know what my aversion is? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This shit. I see you guys once a year and we're talking about what?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: (ignores Richard) It’s random. One theory is that it’s the woman’s system protecting the fetus from that which may be harmful to it. Richard sighs loudly with boredom. Jonathan does a line, passes it to Tim.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: So when Amanda was pregnant with Carrie she started getting really nauseated. And guess what it was?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Oh God, do tell, I’m on the edge my fucking seat. Ron looks at his friends.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: It was me. Richard, Tim and Jonathan look at him, not understanding.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah. My scent. Richard explodes with laughter. Tim and Jonathan follow suit. Ron shakes his head...

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I had to sleep in another room the first four months of the pregnancy! Or else she’d get nauseated! The guys laugh harder.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (faux pain, whiney) But guys, being rejected made me feel small, insecure and unwanted. Laughter. A moment of calm, then:

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (to Jonathan) How’s the world of dating, doc? Jonathan shrugs.  17.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Well, as a doctor, you have an advantage. You can knock them out with drugs and take what belongs to you.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Oh my God. This sparks something in Richard.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Tell them Jonathan. Tell them what you told me about the twenty-year- old patient. Ron was joking. And now this. Jonathan looks at Richard. Tim looks at Jonathan like “you did not.”

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: (an edge) Thanks, Rich. He shakes his head, looks down at the floor. He looks up his friends with a face full of shame.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I don’t think I can stay here for this.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: (to Tim, heartfelt) Timmy, it was a one time thing, I swear. It’s difficult, but Jonathan opens up to his friends. JONATHAN (CONT’D) A year ago, a young patient came in near the end of the day. She was very pretty, to say the least, and it had been awhile for me. (hard, but he presses on) So...I used an anesthetic that allowed me to... He trails off.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Tell them what you did, after you sent the receptionist home.  18.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: I did things with her...I basically lost control...oh God, when I think back...it just makes me... Jonathan looks down, shakes his head, his shoulders shudder...he cannot seem to go on or face his friends... because...it’s too terrible. He looks up, face distorted by the laughter he can no lon contain. Richard howls. Ron and Tim know they’ve been had. And the love it! Hysterical laughter. Jonathan slaps Richard five.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Ally oop!

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Slam dunk! (through laughter) But I have to say, I’m saddened my “friends” don’t even know what I do for a living. I’m an MD for Christ sake, not an anesthesiologist!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talking, doing lines, drinking. Music.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: No, It was that girl, Emily. She was in the house next to us.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Emily, right, but wasn’t it that guy, Simon Tuller?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: It wasn’t Simon, it was Mike Bevans.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter who it was. Unless you want to remind them.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: On Facebook.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Post it.  Laughter. Laughter. Laughter. 19.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Hi Mike! It’s me, Rich, from college! Remember when Emily Sullivan shit on your chest when you were passed out? How’s the wife and kids?!

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Didn’t we used to call it “dick- facing?”

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: But Emily had good reason, because Mike had non-consensual sex with her a few hours before when she was passed out.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Double dick face.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I fucked Emily. Did you guys fuck her?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Guilty as charged, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: I think she gave me crabs.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I fucked her boyfriend, Jeff Snyder.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: That is so fucking great Jonathan! Because I gave Emily the crabs. So I basically gave you the crabs.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: And I fucking knew I had them when I banged her!  They wait. 20.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You know how you get rid of the crabs? It’s a very old American Indian remedy.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You shave one testicle, then, with a good butane torch lighter, you light the other one on fire. Then, as the little fuckers race away from the burning ball you stab them with an ice pic as they run across the shaved one! Laughter. Ron mimes furiously stabbing his balls. Tim tri to change the direction...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Is it possible to have a conversation that’s a little more serious?

dialogues.speaker: RON/RICHARD
dialogues.text: No. Fuck Off.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: That’s what I fucking hate! We can no longer do and say the things that make us fucking feel good.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Saying and doing stupid things makes you feel good?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You know what I mean. Richard rolls a joint and sprinkles coke in it.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: “Cock” doesn’t make me laugh, but schlong does.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Exactly. When men pass forty they can no longer be honest about what makes them laugh. If you are, you are frowned upon.  21.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: And if you’re a father, you lose cred if you display immaturity.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Tim, what word makes you laugh?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: (after he exhales a huge hit of weed) Vulva.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Bangkok.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Time doesn’t just age you, it steals your right to laughter, which is fucking happiness. Which is a fucking crime.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Men are afraid. They think all other guys will think less of them if they loosen up, and so they don’t.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: What is the replacement for happiness?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Bla bla bla, you guys are so fucking pathetic. Richard stands up...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: But you aren't Ron, because you don’t need to participate ina conversation that might be illuminating because you’re such a powerful man. .--and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (calling after Richard) No you fuck, it’s just that I came here to talk about schlongs, vulvas and Bangkok. Jonathan raises the CD cover to his face and snorts a lin  22.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: I think I just found the happiness replacement.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Pass the happiness. Tim snorts a line. Ron checks his Blackberry. Jonathan watches him.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: You should throw that on the fire. Ron is about to answer but he’s distracted by:

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Happy birthday to you... Richard emerges from the hallway, holding a cake with a twelve inch house candle stuck in it at an angle. The oth join in as Richard sets it down.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD / JONATHAN / RON
dialogues.text: Happy birthday to you. Happy birthday dear Timothy, happy birthday to you. Tim stares at it. It’s a Little Mermaid Birthday Cake. Ro and Jonathan laugh.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: It was either that or one with a fire truck. Tim smiles at that.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Aren’t you going to blow it out? Tim looks at his friends. Absurd as the cake is, he’s touched.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I guess I can die now. He leans forward, blows the candle out. His friends cheer Richard moves to the stereo, plays a song.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Come on motherfuckers!  23. He cranks U2’s Out Of Control so loud the house shakes. T guys jump up and dance - they know the words and the beat the dance becomes a reckless awesome spastic ceremonial a invoking the past. The music keeps pumping...but the camera slows, and slows and slows, and pulls back and back and-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera pulls further back...away from the house...hig into the air. We hear A VOICE, objective, observational, anthropological.

dialogues.speaker: THE VOICE
dialogues.text: Was it a sham or was it a ritual? At one time or another, they decided to keep it going. At first, they looked forward to it. It was a reminder of hellion days gone by, unabashed abuse and reigning freedom. But, as responsibilities grew, it became the excuse, the escape, a chance to become young again, to time travel, to hide and run back to that safe place where all mistakes were erased, where the poor choices hadn't been made yet. It reminded them of their original friendship, it was like they could all reach out and feel what it had meant, if only for fleeting moments. It went on this way for years, the ritual, the trip to Jamaica, the year in Vegas, the New York series as it was called. Always an excuse to run and remember. The music, the copious drugs, the feeling of invincibility, it was always the same. The belief they were forever twenty-one and their whole life lay ahead of them, full of promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A police car approaches in the distance.  31 32 33 34 35 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The local Police Chief LAURA BOYDE (late 30’s) drives. Soulful, warm, observational. Laura’s eyes are caught by the four balloons hovering on gate. She looks at them with a subtle smile, like she fin them charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet. The ocean. Sea grass vibrating in the wind. Sun slanting into windows. CD’s and empty booze bottles and dirty glasses all over the living room and kitchen. It’s like nobody is here at all, until we find...

dialogues.speaker: A HAND
dialogues.text: On the round volume button of the stereo. Slowly turning up. We hear the smooth intro of a song introducing this n day as we go

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letting go of the volume control and just standing there, a slash of sunlight, half of him on fire from it, a beer his hand, the song inside of him, and blasting out to- EXT. BACK DECK —- SAME 33 Where Ron and Jonathan sleep on lounge chairs wrapped in blankets, beyond them only the sea. Ron’s eyes blink open from the song, bloodshot and bleary Jonathan listens a beat, then pulls a blanket up over his face. INT. TIM’S ROOM 34 He lays on his back. Stares at the ceiling. He knows this song, knows what it means to him and his friends. A smile fills his eyes. The song continues and takes us to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard walks across the living room floor and out onto--  25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says this like a General rallying his troops.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: We no longer possess the supple flesh of twenty-one-year olds, and how nightmarishly true our brain’s regenerative skills have become with age. Therefore, our only recourse to this sorrowful state we find ourselves in is more booze, treats from the doctor’s bag and the revitalizing elements of the sea! And Richard's voice echoes us into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From behind: four naked men bolting for the water and screaming a collective...

dialogues.speaker: GUYS IN UNISON
dialogues.text: Fuuuuuuuuck!!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayhem emerges, from the sea, oh fuck it’s cold. Coming u for air. We are there with them. The water is cold, they feel it in their older bones. It’s alive-- they look at e other and the sea and space around them. And it is all fine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They guys walk through the sand toward the Porsche, passi joint and drinking beer, in middle of an eighties music r robin trivia speed quiz. They execute it rapid fire.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Buzzcocks.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Orgasm Addict.  39 26.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Psychedelic Furs.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: President Gas.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Love My Way

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Madness.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD/JONATHAN
dialogues.text: (unison) Baggy Trousers.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: That was mine! English Beat.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Fuck that!

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Twist and Crawl. Richard passes the joint to Jonathan.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Depeche Mode.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Personal Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: The Cure.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Boys don’t cry...Killing an arab.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: xX.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Johnny Hit and Run Pauline and I win ‘cause I have fifteen points. The guys push him and mock his “I win ‘cause I have fifte points” in childish voices as we go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waves pound the surf on the beautiful coast.  40 4l 42 43 44 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron stares at his laptop. He looks stressed as he studies the business news on his screen. He takes a deep drink fr his glass to shield him from what he hears. INT. RICHARD’S ROOM - SAME 41 He snorts a line of blow and looks at himself in the mirr It’s not that he likes what he sees or doesn’t like what sees, he is looking at himself with pure objectivity. INT. JONATHAN’S ROOM - SAME 42 Jonathan stands at the dresser in his room with a towel wrapped around him, opens his doctor’s bag. He removes a couple of shirts, pants, his dopp kit. He feels something in the bottom of the bag, and pulls it out: his stethoscope. He looks at it strangely, like he’s surprised to see it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard walks inside, amped and ready. We move with him- EXT. BACK DECK — CONTINUOUS 44 Richard walks out on the deck, sees Tim down on the cliff side nears the water's edge.

dialogues.speaker: A MINUTE LATER
dialogues.text: Richard is smoking a joint, and he moves down to the stai to the edge of the gorgeous promenade cliff area--he move him quietly, sees that Tim’s eyes are closed. He leans ov him, kisses his forehead. Tim’s eyes open, he sees Richard’s upside-down face inche from his own.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (whispered, mock demonic) Wanna go for a ride? And as they look at each other’s face we hear the growing whining sound of the -  45 46 47 48 49 50 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speeding on a long straight road, engine screaming at max RPM. It blasts past us and at the very moment it does we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard drives, Tim sits next to him. Music blasts. They intermittently sing along... Tim holds a baggie of coke and a butter knife. He dips th butter knife into the baggy and scoops out a pile and pla it under Richard's nose. Richard sniffs it. Timmy does a line. Richard accelerates and they smile into the raw freedom o the speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron. Out away from us on the deck. Looking down. We go in close. He’s staring at his Blackberry. The screen has a small graph and text: “mortgage backed securities slammed fourth day in a row.” Ron closes his e tight. His Blackberry rings, gives him a jolt. Amanda's smiling face caller I.D. appears. He clicks igno He moves to the edge of the deck, takes a first step on t steps leading down to the sea as we go-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonathan. Watching as Ron descends down the stairs and disappearing from view.

dialogues.speaker: SAME TIME 49
dialogues.text: Driving fast on the open road, then downshifting and slow for a curve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holiday In Cambodia by the Dead Kennedys plays loud. Tim notices a tiny figurine of a man hanging from the rear vi mirror by a string.  51 52 53 29. He looks at the side Richard’s face as Richard accelerate into a long straight...

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: (quietly) I’m going to miss you. Richard doesn’t hear it. The Porsche picks up speed. Tim cranks the music LOUD as they bend into the speed, race i the moment, blast into their shared past and present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunes in the distance, the car slowing. Turning off the paved road onto a dirt road. Towards the dunes in the distance and the distant sea. They see an abandoned graffiti sprayed building. The car skids to a violent stop. They get out with the mu still blaring. Richard takes a leak against the wall, and Tim does a line. They simply explore this outpost of desolation, without w and with comfort. They see color and violence and expression. They see themselves. They get back in the speed machine, fishtail down the dir road, straightens, roars off leaving a twisting plume of behind it.

dialogues.speaker: SECONDS LATER
dialogues.text: The Porsche rounds a corner, going fast faster fastest... and careens down the sandy road over a big bump and into air and lands with a thud and gets stuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard and Tim look at each other. And burst out laughin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonathan and Ron are making blender drinks in the kitchen Ron's Blackberry vibrates. He looks irritated, then he re it, smiles, shows it to Jonathan. It’s a text from Richar

dialogues.speaker: HELP
dialogues.text: 54 30. As their eyes meet we go-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance we see the Porsche at the base of a monumental sand dune. We see two small figures on top of dune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim and Richard on top of the dune. Tim squats down and grabs a fist full of sand, stands. He sifts it through hi fingers intermittently.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: This is the best I’ve felt all year. Being here with you guys.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yes indeed.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: But I know it’s because I can’t feel anything. The drugs.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s not. Maybe it’s us being together. Don’t just rule that out.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: That's why we do this.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: A question, Rich. Is that why we do this?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I look forward to it. I want it to happen. It’s kind of a Christmas. Or if you’re a non-Christian, then it’s like a birthday. And if you're a Jehovah's Witness and you don’t celebrate birthdays then it’s like the day you get married. Though less subdued than you might imagine the typical Jehovah's Witness Wedding to be.  31.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: The Jehovah's Witness wedding... (removes the butter knife from his pocket, imitates sniffing a line off it) None of this?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Doubtful.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: But at your wedding...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (absurd to think of it) My wedding!

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: When’s that? Richard looks at the car.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: We’re stuck man. Tim looks at Richard. Pretends he can’t see him.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Richard? Richard? Richard smiles, knows he’s busted.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Was that the ‘non-rebuttal rebuttal?’

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I don’t think that qualifies. But it was evasive.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Why don’t you have a woman, Rich? I mean, I know you have women, but like, THE woman.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Why on earth would I need “THE” woman. Why why why why?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: You know, to tame you. Train you. They laugh.  32.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I’m house trained. Untamed, perhaps, but I don’t piss on the carpets.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: It’s okay to let a girl love you.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (gestures to himself) I mean really, who wants this? My mother. She does. But she’s... He makes a gesture like his Mother is somewhere in the ether... A beat.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: You fuck lots of women, but have you ever loved one?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I love them all. You can’t love them all if you only love one.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: If that’s true that’s interesting.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Let me tell you what I think, Timothy. I think when they really see me, don’t like what they see.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: You make sure of that.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (thinks, then) Lot’s of guys do.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Because then it’s commitment.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (re: the dune) Look where we are.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: The men have mounted the dune.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Mount. Dune. Good strong words.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: We are duned.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I have my friends, Timmy. I have my job. (then) And I have my dream that I’1l write another book. They are both distracted by a honking horn....... A TOW TRUCK. Approaching fast. Ron rides inside with THE DRIVER. Jonathan hangs off the side like a fireman in a Fourth of July parade, cigarette mouth, sunglasses on, long scarf around his neck trailing the wind. In his free hand he holds pitcher of Margaritas and glass Tim and Richard look at him from the top of the dune. His grin is insane, beautiful. Then look at each other and smile. TOW TRUCK POV: Richard and Tim. Two figures against the late afternoon sky...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys find old cardboard and plastic trays and slide a roll and glide down the dunes like ecstatic children. Abandoned and reckless and careening. Free. The danger takes us to sunset and deep inside their glee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house. Cocktail hour. Beautifully peaceful against th evening sky backdrop. INT. HOUSE - RICHARD’S ROOM - EVENING 56 A large vaulted room, one small mattress. One lamp. Richa lays on one of the beds, drink in hand. A small door near the floor catches his eye...  57 58 59 34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim watches Ron from the kitchen window. Ron is on his ce and looks panicked and upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are right with Ron now. We see the deep stress in his face in the shadows of the flood lights.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (shocked, quiet) What? The S.E.C and a fucking government subpoena? Jesus Christ. Ron listens. Says a barely audible “yeah” three times and then clicks off. He rolls his neck as if trying to twist stress out. Takes a swig from the cocktail in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim walks out of the sliding glass door holding a tray wi wedges of lime, tequila shots, salt.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Need a drink? Ron shakes his nearly full cocktail, shakes his head. Tak a deep breath. Tim sets the tray down on the railing.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I’m good now. Sorry for yelling... some incompetencies in my office... Tim nods, sips his shot, catches the panic and fear in Ro eyes for a FLASH but Ron masks it. Ron drains his cocktai in one long ferocious pull, takes the shot from the tray Tim offered and knocks it back as well.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s more like it. Tim reaches into his pocket, holds out an old Polaroid to - the four guys in college.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Recognize any one here? Ron’s studies it. He bursts out laughing but it’s forced weird.  60 61 35.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Jesus, who the fuck are those people? What’s with that hair? Tim laughs, drains his shot. Ron glances back at the phot loses himself in it for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So fucking long ago. Ron's face reveals a flash of sadness as he sees his youn self.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t recognize that guy.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I recognize you. A beat, then...

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you ever get scared?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (too strong) Why the fuck would I get scared? Tim bristles. INT. RICHARD’S ROOM —- SAME - NIGHT 60 There is a 24X24 painting laying flat on the floor. Richard hovers over it on his knees. It’s a child’s paint of a lighthouse near a cliff. It looks like the entire ocean is on fire. The title is “This is the end of the World” It's signed by Bobby, 9 1/

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron looks at Tim. Hold this. Then...

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I’m not sure what you’re asking me.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I guess I’m asking you if your life turned out the way you thought it would.  62 36.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Why? Because you’re asking yourself that? Tim doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can’t we just have a good time? That dreamy shit ain’t for me. Not now it’s not.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Okay, very hunter and gatherer of you.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: That’s why I love you, Tim. You were always a little more evolved than me. Maybe being part girl can do that for you, help you develop that sensitivity. Tim’s eyes are pained. That was below the belt. And Ron regrets saying it. Softer now...

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you know what I think? I think I don’t want to think, and that’s why I came here. (sincere) Maybe you came here for another reason?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I came here to be with the people who mean something to me.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: There ya go. Now, shouldn’t we go inside and spend time with them? And as Ron waits for Tim’s response...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark, save candles throwing shadows around the room and flickering in the reflection of the bath water. Jonathan lays in a large bathtub, glass of booze on his belly. Music plays softly on a boom box. Richard enters quietly, takes in the scene, the music, silently kneels down next the tub. Jonathan looks at him.  37.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Open your mouth and close your eyes. Jonathan does. Richard reaches in his pocket, drops a pil on Jonathan’s tongue. RICHARD (CONT’D) Guess. Jonathan feels the shape of the pill on his tongue.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Dilaudid, a morphine derivative. (beat) I had a patient who offered me a large sum of money for a prescription. Changed the landscape of my clientele. She had many friends. Jonathan opens his bloodshot eyes, looks in Richard's.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: And this became your practice. Rather than the one you imagined you would have. Jonathan is silent, then:

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: I remember, in college, right after we met, I remember saying, ‘you can write about people, and I can save lives.’ Richard taps the surface of the water every few seconds, creating ripples on which the candlelight rolls and shimm JONATHAN (CONT’D) I used to go with my father on house calls. One time, when I was eight, my father was in the next room with a man who had bone cancer. I was in the living room with the man’s two daughters and his wife, and the man was screaming in pain. (beat) They were staring at me like my father was going to save him. I wanted to tell them what my father told me before we got there, that he was going to die. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 63 64 65 38. JONATHAN (CONT’D) Soon the guy stopped screaming, my father probably shot four hundred milligrams of morphine into him. When my father walked out of the room, they looked at him like he was some sort of savior. (then) And so did I. Very slowly Jonathan sinks into the water and disappears under the shimmering surface.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The surface of the ocean. ANGLE ON: Docked boats, the sun rising in the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance: A boat slowly rising and falling on a gently rolling sea. EXT. CAPTAIN BOB’S FISHING BOAT - THE BOW - TWO HOURS LAT

dialogues.speaker: MID-MORNING
dialogues.text: Richard stares out to the sea and dramatically quotes fro Moby Dick while Jonathan and Ron watch.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: ‘All that most maddens and torments,all truth with malice in it; all that cracks the sinews and cakes the brain. He looks at them. And suddenly goes pale. And pukes over the edge of the boat. Jonathan and Ron look at each other, back at Richard.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: This was such a great idea, Rich!  66 39.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, one of the best you’ve ever had! (beat, imitates Richard) ‘Hey guys! How about we go fishing!?’

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: And it’s so OUTSTANDING that we’re going to be out here alllll day.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (weakly) Fuck you guys...

dialogues.speaker: ON THE MAIN DECK
dialogues.text: Captain Bob sits with Tim on bolted down deck chairs. Tim fishing rod ticks slowly as the line draws out. Tim gets out of his chair, looks back at the coast, takes in.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BOB
dialogues.text: Nice isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: God yes.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BOB
dialogues.text: Lotta boats use sonar to track fish, for a guaranteed catch. But I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: We're along for the ride more than anything. Captain Bob looks at Richard bent over the edge of the railing.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BOB
dialogues.text: I can see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron sniffs a line of coke. Ron removes a pill from his pocket, swallows it. Richard dumps out more coke from a baggy, looks at Jonathan.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You need some.  Jonathan looks exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: I need that. He indicates a small bed in the back of the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Have a lie down ya fookin party pooper. 40. Jonathan stumbles to the bed and lies down. Richard looks Ron, indicates the cabin door. RICHARD (CONT’D) Cover for me. (as he leans in to snort) I’m a 45 year old man hiding drugs from a guy named Captain Bob. Fuck me.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I could buy this boat, yet I’m hiding like a fucking twelve year old.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Isn't that the point? To remain young? Richard snorts loud, straightens up, holds a finger to hi nose. Ron puts his hand to his chest.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Beating like crazy. Richard smiles. The devilish one.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Means you’re alive. He takes a slug of booze from the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Remember last year, Vegas?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Last year was Hawaii, the year before was Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Right, right. Fucking mind is going.  67 68 41.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Don’t think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waves. Sea. Jonathan sits near Captain Bob and Tim, who a having a quiet conversation as they lean against the rail of the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He’s looking at pictures of Miles on his phone. He flashe through them quickly, we see Miles’ life- a baby up to th present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron and Richard are outside now, side by side on the smal deck at the front of the boat. Ron pulls a bottle of booz from his jacket, takes a drink.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You know I didn’t mean that, about your daughter's friends. Or your daughter. Ron looks at him, a bit surprised.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Wow. Goin’ soft on me. Richard smiles, absolved.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Just makin’ sure.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Goes without saying but thanks for saying it. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But...a tight sixteen year-old ass- They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you're a high school teacher?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yes I am.  42.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You ever tempted...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (dead serious, means it) Nope. (then) How’s Amanda?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Man, sometimes I find it hard to believe I chose so well. I wake up some days and feel her warm body sleeping next to me, and I just--

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You’re lucky, Ron. Ron, despite being high, knows this in his bones, nods.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: She doesn’t push me. She doesn’t question me. We respect what we both do, and what we do is defined. I know my role... (beat, under his breath) I don’t know why I have done the things that I’ve done. Richard turns to him. Not even sure he just heard that right.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You look like shit, man.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: So do you.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Fuck you. They laugh. We hear the dull hum of the boat engine as Captain Bob navigates to another spot. The lines chop.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You still writing?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I write all the time, Ron. (twisted smile) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I write report cards, I write on chalk boards, I write to the school board to raise money and I write, ‘Dear God, hey man, when you get a chance, can you tell me why I have nothing to write about?’ (then) So yes, I write a lot. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: What’s all that gibberish mean?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I write, but it’s shit. It’s like I'm disconnected from every experience I’ve ever had. I might as well be writing about the mating habits of the Hercules beetle in South America during a drought. Like I give a shit. (then) I’m an English teacher now. For now, I am a teacher.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Those who can’t do... Richard starts to chop a line of coke...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Do this. Ron stares at him. Wants to say something. Doesn’t know what to say. Then he takes a long breath, looks at Richar

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I’m in deep trouble Richard. Deep, over my head drowning trouble. Richard stares in Ron’s eyes, but doesn’t say anything or why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim and Captain Bob are talking. Jonathan is in a deep sl fifteen feet away from them under a canopy. Captain Bob stands next to a fishing rod, which ticks slo as the line draws out. Tim sits on a deck chair.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BOB
dialogues.text: So it’s reunion, huh?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: We all went to college together. Jonathan and Richard have known each other since grade school. We meet every year, somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BOB
dialogues.text: Nice to catch up. Waves slap against the hull of the boat. CAPTAIN BOB (CONT’D) I left school when I was fourteen and the sea kept me moving, so I never did have any reunions. The ones I remember are with my wife after long fishing trips back when I did commercial work. We see a trace of dread on Tim’s face. Is this guy going talk his ear off? CAPTAIN BOB(CONT’D) She died 11 years ago. Cancer. I spent most days just drifting out here, trying to understand. (adjusts a fishing line) Suddenly I noticed so many miserable people arguing with each other, husbands and wives treating each other like animals. Tim listens, engaged, no longer worried about being held captive. CAPTAIN BOB(CONT’D) I stopped feeling sorry for myself and felt sorry for them. I realized I was lucky to have felt something that looked or smelled or resembled real love. A lot of folks never taste that. Tim stands, moves to the railing, looks out at the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I tasted it. And it made every day... (searches for the word) ...annointed. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nothing mattered when we were together, and when we were apart, I felt him like I felt my own breath. Captain Bob looks at him, relating Tim’s love for a man t the love he had for his wife, sensing how deep it was.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BOB
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Johan died five years ago. In an accident. Captain Bob moves from the rod to the railing near Tim. T stare out to sea.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN BOB
dialogues.text: You believe in heaven? Tim eyes the waves swirling below him. Tim smiles at Capt Bob.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: Actually, I don’t. And off Captain Bob’s look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance, the boat chugs home slowly, making its w to shore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys stumble off, sunburned and drugged, not the ordi tourists seen round here. Captain Bob watches them with a mixture of curiosity and sadness as they meander up the d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seafood restaurant in town. Mixed of people. Richard drin at the bar when the hostess, RANDI (20) on her name tag, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: Did you have the large order to go?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: How many orders to go do you have?  46.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: One.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: The fine art of deduction says it’s me. Richard looks her over-

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: Would you like to pay now? -and sees how beautiful she is.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Would you like to come home with my order? She laughs innocently. She’s pretty when she does.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: I’m working. And you should work on your lines.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: If I work on my lines will you consider my offer? She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: No. Richard takes out his wallet, removes a credit card, hand over. She leaves. The strapping young BARTENDER (24) glar at Richard.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: That's a fairly possessive expression on your face. She your girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Then why are you looking at me like that? Bartender stares at Richard with a contemptuous smile, le over the bar to get closer.  73 47.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: You're pathetic and drunk. And she'd never go out with an old man like you. Richard knocks back his drink, takes a hundred dollar bil out of his wallet and lays it down.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Thank you. The world needs more people like you. Keep it. Bartender is not sure how to respond. Richard spins wobbl off the bar stool, moves to the podium near front door. Five large bags of food are being brought out. Randi has check ready. A subtle flirtation between them as he signs

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: Looks like you’re feeding an army.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Leave with me. Walk out without looking back.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: You're really high. He signs his credit card slip. Grabs a business card and writes his cell number, address and gate code on it.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I’m in town for three days. Me and my friends. We are harmless and fun. If you plan on tossing that card instead of calling me, wait till I’m ten minutes away so I don’t feel it. I’m sensitive that way. He grabs his take-away and leaves. Randi’s eyes follow hi out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've moved the dining room table into the center of th living room. Tons of food remains, music on, muted TV, fi in fireplace. Ron folds a lobster tail into the shape of a Vagina. Tim stares at a painting on the wall. Richard is very drunk, sits back in his chair with his eyes closed.  74 48. Jonathan walks in, chipper, wearing a doctor’s coat. He h his stethoscope round his neck. He stands in front of Tim looks in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: You...you are very, very sick. Jonathan pulls a pill from his pocket, holds it above Tim mouth. Tim opens his mouth and Jonathan drops it in. Jonathan moves to Ron, listens to his heartbeat with his stethoscope. Makes a clucking sound with his tongue, look in Ron’s eyes. JONATHAN (CONT’D) One for the journals. I’ve never seen it before. Open wide. He does. Jonathan drops one pill in his mouth, then anoth Richard looks at Jonathan coming to him. Richard opens hi mouth like Alex when he’s being fed in A Clockwork Orange Richard swallows it and pops his mouth back open. Jonathan drops another. JONATHAN (CONT’D) Now, all of you, put the lime in the coconut, and call me in the morning. A beat later Richard’s iPhone buzzes. He reaches takes it from the table and looks at the screen: We're here. Seconds later there’s a KNOCK KNOCK KNOCK on the door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard is smiling as he answers the door. His smile fade when he sees past Randi to her friends - FOUR GUYS in the early 20’s and a sexy girl with pale skin. Jonathan, Ron and Tim say hello. Randi introduces intellectual RYAN, nerdy ETHAN, effeminate COLE, an exoti looking girl named RAVEN and JONAH “my boyfriend.” Richard’s face tightens when Randi introduces Jonah. Rand reaches in her purse, pulls out a plastic bag with large capsules inside, dangles it teasingly before them.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: You guys know what an MX Missile is?  75 49. Richard, Ron, Tim and Jonathan look at each other, play d

dialogues.speaker: RANDI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Virgins. They all laugh. Who’s the virgin now motherfucker? How Soon Is Now? kicks in loud and takes us to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonathan and Ethan. Music in B.G. Ethan holds a capsule i one hand and a tiny baggie of shrooms in the other.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Your garden variety MX missile. M as in mushrooms and X as in X. Jonathan takes the capsule, pops it in his mouth, knocks back with his drink. He holds out his hand, Ethan pinches some mushrooms out and hands them to him. Jonathan chews swallows them.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It should hit you in half an hour. It’s better when you're sober, with an empty stomach and no other drugs.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: You sound like a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I’m studying to be one. Jonathan smiles at that, reaches into his pocket, pulls o some pills, A LOT of pills...holds them out as an offerin Ethan. Ethan declines. Jonathan knocks them back and wash them down with booze.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Holy shit, man. You’re letting your demon out. Jonathan looks at Ethan, shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: I’m on vacation. Off Ethan’s reaction-  76 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron, Randi, Richard, Raven and Ryan. Music loud, chop, snort, sip, pour, ice crack, laugh, shot of tequila on glistening lips. We jump in mid-conversation. It’s fast a furious, everyone talking fast, over and around each othe coke fueled.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: (to Ron) You still have sex with your wife?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: That's private, Randolf.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: Ha! That means you don’t.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: In fact, I do.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: He does. A lot.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (to Richard) How the fuck would you know?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: She's always too tired to fuck me! Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: RAVEN
dialogues.text: (to Richard) Who do you have sex with?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You?

dialogues.speaker: RAVEN
dialogues.text: You're not my type. (xe: Ron) He’s more like it.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: This is a test, Ronnie.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: (to Ron) How do you have sex with the same person over and over year in and year out?  77 51.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Versus a bunch of random people over time?

dialogues.speaker: RAVEN
dialogues.text: (to Ron, sincere) I fucking love that you said that.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: My parents still play pound hound. I hear them.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: The first time I heard my Mom and Dad fuck I thought my Dad was beating her up. I started screaming and crying and kicking their bedroom door. Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: How did they explain themselves?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: My Father knew just how soothe my seven year old mind. He got down on one knee, looked me in the eyes and gently said, ‘Son, I wasn’t hurting your Mother, I was simply banging her fucking brains out.” Laughter. The chatter and laughter continues as Raven leans back an peeks in the living room. She sees Cole by the fireplace talking with Tim. Cole and Tim look up and meet Raven’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan and Jonathan sit on the sofa. Ethan exhales a hit o pot, looks at Jonathan like he’s trying to remember something, then...

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I see what you mean about medical breakthroughs. They’re frustrating because you don’t know how they apply.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: You read a headline that says, there’s a connection between ovarian cancer and Juniper berries. And then what? (then) It’s like masturbating with Hulk Hands on. A beat, then Jonathan eyes roll back in his head and grab his face and leans back into the sofa. Ethan looks at him

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I think your MX Missile just launched. And as Jonathan nods from behind his hands and groans...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole and Tim sit on the couch. Raven is by herself behind them, swaying to the music. Tim and Cole are in the middl of talking...

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Oh my God I'd love to live in Austria.

dialogues.speaker: RAVEN
dialogues.text: I just imagine gingerbread houses and beer. Tim laughs.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: And Baroque architecture and bratvurst.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: (mimics Tim’s perfect pronunciation) Bratvurst.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: And Beethoven.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: You have to say ‘bratvurst’ again.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: (grinning) Most definitely not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 78 53. Cole whips out his iPhone, slides close to Tim, takes a picture of them together. He shows Tim and Tim smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ODE TO MISTER JOHN HUGHES. A song comes on. The guys know it and Randi and her friends know it. You know it. Everyo loves it. A group dance breaks out, a spontaneous drug-fueled quasi choreographed age barrier-destroying dance, a tribal prim vortex they all get lost inside of. INT. RICHARD’S ROOM - NIGHT - HALF HOUR LATER 78 Richard bursts in with Jonah, whips a hardcover book off dresser: Reel Around The Fountain, by Richard Leclair.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: You wrote it? Richard nods, opens it to a random page, reads out loud.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: ‘Death had been installed in our home, and my Mother hadn’t ordered it. It was a delivery from Satan for being good or a lesson from God about life, and she hid it deep inside her where I couldn’t see it, because she thought it was what my dead father would have wanted. But over the years the pain slowly oozed out of her hiding place like poison, and consumed her from within.’ The words sound new and strange to Richard. He and Jonah’ eyes meet. He hands the book to Jonah, who looks it over, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Is it autobiographical?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Every first novel is.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: How'd it do?  79 54.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: It made the New York Times Best- seller list for a couple of weeks.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: That is insane! So when’s the next one?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: We should get out of here. Richard heads for the door. Jonah watches him, confused b his response, then follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonathan and Ethan smoke pot. Music from house in B.G.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: ..-my Dad is the town doctor here. Unless someone needs a specialist, then they go to San Francisco. And his dad was the town doctor. It was an unspoken thing, that I’d go to med school. I like it, though. Are you an MD? Jonathan takes a beat before he answers.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: A lot of my patients come to me for a certain brand of medical care they otherwise wouldn’t have access to. Ethan’s look tells Jonathan he doesn’t follow. Ethan hits off the joint, waits... JONATHAN (CONT’D) I provide them with prescriptions for pain killers, when in fact they really don’t need them. Ethan, instinctively and without judgement...

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: That is spiritually filthy. How do you like, look at yourself?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: I get rid of all the mirrors.  55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron and Ryan are front of the fireplace talking. Ryan han a CD cover with coke on it to Ron.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: ..-anyway, this rich guy Greenberg comes to town and he’s building this ugly twenty-five thousand foot mansion right on the ocean in front of my mom’s house. Ron snorts a line. RYAN(CONT’D) My mom’s tried to stop him legally but he just crushes her with his money. The fucker is actually putting in a helicopter pad.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Hey, if the guy can live like a king, why the fuck not?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Why is total excess equated with living like a king? Why do people need all that shit?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (self-evident) Because the shit is there. Ryan shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: That's crazy. You actually believe that?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I don’t believe that, I know that.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Well, you can’t know something if it’s a choice.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Is that some college bullshit you learned from your philosophy professor? This throws Ryan.  81 56.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: I’m just saying, people don’t need certain things, even though they might think they do. Ron’s transformation from light to dark is instant.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: (quiet, vicious) How the fuck would you have any idea what people need? Ron looks in Ryan’s eyes, squeezes the glass in his own h like he’s trying to crush it. He does. Blood flows. He doesn’t look down, he keeps his eyes locked on Ryan’s.

dialogues.speaker: RON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Talk to me when the naivete wears off. Ron gets up, walks away. Ryan follows with his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard, Jonah and Randi. Richard pours a large glass of vodka. Richard is so drunk now it’s hard for him to stand straig

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What kind of fiction do you write? He holds out the bottle to them, refill? They both declin

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: I just write stories. Things that mean something to me.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Ah the personal stuff.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: He’s great, really amazing.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: So you submit them, like quarterlies and crap like that? Randi and Jonah look at each other and smile.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: My last one ran in The New Yorker.  57.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: We were all so proud. Richard looks at Jonah, mock impressed.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (with an edge) And there will be another story. And then some heat. Then you’1l write the novel. And then fucking what? Jonah is not sure what to make of this. Randi looks at Richard. Then Jonah. Then Richard again.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. Is there something wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: You published a book. I’d love to be able to do that.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You remind me of someone. (drunkenly waves his drink as he speaks, it splashes on the floor) ) You think it’s just...it’s just going to happen. And it will, it will. But it won’t be anything like you dreamed it would. Jonah stares at him. Then...

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Who do I remind you of? Richard is too drunk to answer, thumbs himself in the che with the hand holding the drink.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: (strong) You? No way. I don’t think so. Richard seems confused by this, it seems to penetrate the inebriation.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I was like that, all excited about this! And that! And it was all gonna be...so fuck-ing rosy...so fucking...  82 58. He trails off...

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: Jonah’s not like that, he doesn’t think everything is going to be a certain way. He just loves to write.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: You don’t have to speak for me- She leans to him.

dialogues.speaker: RANDI
dialogues.text: You have all this disillusionment because it’s easier than being honest. And you think he’1l be like you when he’s older because it makes you feel better. (beat) Stay cynical. Jonah tries to quiet her.

dialogues.speaker: JONAH
dialogues.text: Randi... Richard goes pale, pained, embarrassed by what he knows t see. He looks down, mumbles softly...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I still love to write. (beat) I still do. I just... Jonah and Randi look at him, and then each other, silentl communicating it is time to leave...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raven, Cole and Tim are on Tim’s bed, touching, exploring each other. All of this is in almost total darkness.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: I am so high. This feels sooooo good. Close on Tim. Something happening in his eyes. The mood, the room, the vitality of Raven and Cole, it’s slipping a from him. Cole reaches down to unzip Tim’s pants. Tim sto him.  59.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I can’t. Tim shifts, extracts himself from their embrace, sits on edge of the bed. Raven sits next to him, naked. Her long black hair shines in the dim light, pale skin looks ghost She stares at Tim, leans in close, gently licks his lips.

dialogues.speaker: RAVEN
dialogues.text: You feel it? She puts his hand between her legs. Says this softly.

dialogues.speaker: RAVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want this? Tim looks away. She gently turns his head towards hers, looks him in the eye. She is loving, sexual, free. Tim is uncomfortable as he takes in her features.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: You look like my sister. Jill. Raven giggles playfully.

dialogues.speaker: RAVEN
dialogues.text: Not into incest? She says it lightly, she means nothing at all by it. Tim to hide how horrible the words make him feel.

dialogues.speaker: RAVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You should ask her to come over so I can judge for myself. I like girls too. Tim starts to feel his insides pulling out. Cole and Rave are too high to see it. Tim Closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: It’s impossible. (beat) She's dead. Three bodies in the dark. All we hear is the waves outsid the window and the din of the distant party. Cole stops moving for a beat. Then lays his head on Tim's shoulder, strokes him, comforts him. Raven takes his hand

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: How did she die?  This is sacred, private. He speaks numbly.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: I killed her. Her and my boyfriend. I killed them car. Five years ago. I lived and they died. Cole looks like he has stopped breathing. druggy and profound, the witchy savant. 60. Tim’s closed eyes open, tears fall. in my I was drunk. But Raven is cool, She takes his face into her hands, stares into his eyes, accepts it. She kno pain and love.

dialogues.speaker: RAVEN
dialogues.text: This life, this earth, is hell, this place we live. This is a state, a stop on the way. True Nirvana only happens when we die. They were lucky. Death is something to attain. Tim lets this pour through his mind and body. Cole holds him, tighter, and fiercer. calm. Raven says this with clarity and

dialogues.speaker: RAVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you see them alive when you close your eyes to go to sleep? Tim relents, opens up, lets Cole kiss him. Raven rubs his skin, she feels exactly how it feels to him, and where he needs her touch.

dialogues.speaker: RAVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (softly) You'll see them again. will forgive you. And they Raven puts her hand on Tim’s beating heart, whispers to h

dialogues.speaker: RAVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me be her. Cole hears this, leans into Tim’s ear.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
